lexUnit.name: lift.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a platform or compartment housed in a shaft for raising and lowering people or things.

sentence.text: Once again he had to take the fearsome lift , and once again he only just got out before its great teeth sprang back on him .
Pascoe took the lift back down a floor .
The decision to build the lift could not have been taken lightly ; it only makes sense as part of a scheme of general improvement .
He was questioned about the decision not to build a lift at Watford but instead to renew the narrow locks .
She entered the lift and impatiently pressed the button for the lower ground .
They entered a lift , Casey having been taken through a more private entrance to the rear of the building .
The ragged edges of the hole glinted sharply , and Jesus knew that any failed attempt to enter the Lift would be likely to result in his being sliced to ribbons within a matter of seconds .
Like someone sleepwalking , she entered the lift , ` Bye , " she said huskily , and as the lift sailed upwards she was n't conscious of thinking of anything .
This made the total cost of erecting the lift to be an estimated £27,000 .
However , during training , decisions such as when to leave the lift and start to get back to the field are too often taken by the instructor .
Still on autopilot , she left the lift two Levels below 281 , and went unstoppably through the narrow sideways and gangpaths until she reached the room .
Leaving the lift at the third floor , instead of the fourth , he stood outside Alexandra 's front door , listening .
It was considerably later that I discovered that the teenage office lad had been strapped and bound with tape and left in the lift on the top floor .
There was nearly a chance when he got locked in a lift at the Horseguards Hotel the other day , but the prospect of being out of the front line for a few hours was more than he could bear .
A few minutes later , feeling decidedly the worse for wear after the last Armagnac had been downed , Mark moved unsteadily into the lift with his voluptuous mate .
He moved towards the lift and then turned back and said , ` Oh , by the way .
Then a week later I ran into the lift at the Tube and he was the only other person there .
Mr Swanson arrived at the reception area and was shown to the private lift that went straight to Miranda 's office on the top floor .
She walked to the lift , smiled at the porter , and stepped inside .
As Adam walked out of the lift , he was surprised to be met by someone of his own age .
Sophie opened the door and walked to the lift .
He walked away to the desk , collecting his key , and as he walked towards the lifts he flicked a quick glance back to the girl who 'd been brought up as his daughter .
He had walked over to the lift and waited with her too , she recalled without effort , as Lubor walked to the lift with her and pressed the lift call button .

European conference venues suffer from chronic diseases : small doors , narrow stairs , no lifts at all or tiny lifts added to the building as an afterthought , poor electrics , low ceilings , ` miles away " kitchens , staff curfews , meaningless rules and no ramps .
Though lifts and fire stairs have been newly built , many of the original structures -- particularly the timber beams and cast iron columns -- remain .
A scene dock and scenery truck lift will be constructed which will simplify the ` get in " arrangements for the big musical productions which tour to the Playhouse .

The goods or service lift is entered from the backstairs area behind the passenger lift and is controlled by a set of three ` semi-automatic " push buttons , the third being for stopping the lift at any desired point .

The lift they entered was crowded , forcing them to stand close together , the brush of Luke 's jacket sleeve against her bare arm adding to the difficulty of trying to sort out what she was going to say to him before she agreed to get into the car with him .
